<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_stat:
```c
int lfs_stat(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path, struct lfs_info *info) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_stat(%p, \"%s\", %p)", (void*)lfs, path, (void*)info);

    err = lfs_stat_(lfs, path, info);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_stat -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_stat:
#define LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0)
...
#define LFS_UNLOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg)
...
#define LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
static int lfs_stat_(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path, struct lfs_info *info) {
    lfs_mdir_t cwd;
    lfs_stag_t tag = lfs_dir_find(lfs, &cwd, &path, NULL);
    if (tag < 0) {
        return (int)tag;
    }

    // only allow trailing slashes on dirs
    if (strchr(path, '/') != NULL
            && lfs_tag_type3(tag) != LFS_TYPE_DIR) {
        return LFS_ERR_NOTDIR;
    }

    return lfs_dir_getinfo(lfs, &cwd, lfs_tag_id(tag), info);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: static int lfs_stat_(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path, struct lfs_info *info) {
explanation: The rest of the code does not appear to modify function parameters themselves. In lfs_stat: LFS_LOCK and LFS_UNLOCK are macros that do not assign to the lfs parameter (their definitions show no modification), LFS_TRACE is empty, and lfs_stat simply forwards its parameters to lfs_stat_ without assigning to them. In lfs_stat_: uses of strchr(path, '/') and lfs_tag_type3(tag) only read from path or use local variables; lfs_dir_getinfo(lfs, &cwd, lfs_tag_id(tag), info) may modify the object pointed to by info (which is permitted by the rule) but does not modify the info pointer itself. Therefore only the function signature of lfs_stat_ (shows path is a pointer parameter) and the call passing &path to lfs_dir_find are flagged for investigation, since passing the address of the parameter allows the callee to modify the pointer parameter itself, which would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
